conclusion: Use principles of static equilibrium involving frictional forces to find mass ratio.
Frictional force on block A is at maximum: f_A = μ_2 (m_A g + m_B g).
Normal force from ground on block A is F_N = m_A g + m_B g.
Frictional force on block B is at maximum: f_B = μ_1 m_B g.
Normal force from block A on block B is F_{N1} = m_B g.
Vertical component of frictional force on block B counterbalances its weight: f_B = m_B g.
Equate maximum frictional force on A and B: μ_2 (m_A g + m_B g) = μ_1 m_B g.
Divide both sides by m_B g to solve for mass ratio.
Solve for mass ratio: (m_A/m_B) = (μ_1 - μ_2) / μ_2.
Final answer: mass ratio of block A to block B is (μ_1 - μ_2) / μ_2.
